awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Unified Design Framework for Advanced Power Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
ABSTRACT

Power electronics are ubiquitous in the modern technological age.  They enable battery-powered mobile electronics, energy-efficient lighting, high-performance electric vehicles, renewable energy, advanced medical technologies, and prolific computational power in the smart home.  By 2030, 80% of all electricity in the United States will be processed through at least one power converter.  In consumer applications, power is often processed through five or more functionally disparate converters, each of which is individually designed for the target application.  Rapid advances in constituent technologies, circuit topologies, and control schemes have enabled high-performance and high-efficiency in many applications, but require considerable dedication of design effort to achieve.  The goal of this research is to develop the fundamental knowledge and centralized resources necessary to bridge the gap between current approaches to the design of power conversion technologies and true, formal design optimization techniques.  In order to promulgate new approaches to the design and application of power conversion, the project integrates the research program with education developments that seek to broaden participation and effectively train the future generation of power electronics engineers.  Research products will be incorporated into the curriculum at the graduate and undergraduate levels, and into pre-college outreach and engineering discovery events.  At all levels, the education program emphasized hands-on design-oriented experiences to engage participants.

The design of high-performance power electronics is a complex interplay of nonlinearities, approximations, intuition, and prototype/revision cycles.  Attempts at optimization are limited due to the inherent complexity of the design and performance spaces.  The former is high constrained, containing both continuous and discrete, ordered and unordered dimensions.  The latter is multi-objective and highly non-convex.  This project advances the state-of-the art in converter analysis and modeling, facilitating the application of formal design optimization techniques for greater design capabilities and achievable performance.  The approach leverages a framework developed from techniques in nonlinear element modeling, reduced-order converter modeling, and switching analysis of power converters.  By integrating these efforts, while creating an open-source characterization repository, the developed techniques will allow computationally efficient and highly accurate design and modeling of power converters, significantly advancing the state of the field.  The result will be a new analytical framework that allows designers to rapidly select topology, operating mode, semiconductor and passive devices, and switching functions which will achieve maximal performance in a given application.  The framework is developed to retain designer engagement, allowing for shorter design cycles, while providing the tools to allow a greater level of achievable design optimization.

por.por_cntn:
The framework developed in this work simplifies the task of selecting a power conversion circuit and schematic-level implementation to meet a user-defined application and performance specification.  The approach uses a discrete-time framework, including extensions which allow the framework to inherently model nonlinearities present in the operation of advanced power electronics.  These results are then coupled with a continuously-growing database of experimental and analytical results that ensures the highest degree of accuracy possible given an inherently uncertain design space.  Leveraging these two, the research has developed techniques for holistic optimization of power conversion circuits.  The result is a new analytical framework that allows designers to rapidly select topology, operating mode, semiconductor and passive devices, and switching functions which will achieve maximal performance in a given application.  The framework is developed to retain designer engagement, allowing for shorter prototyping cycles in the design process.

This work does not fully-automate the physical design of the converter, though the approach is synergistic with such efforts. The final prototype construction ( e.g. PCB layout, heatsink design, physical construction of magnetics, controller implementation, protection circuitry) are completed using established techniques.  The goals of this project are to develop tools to aid the designer by providing insight necessary to reach an optimal, model-based circuit design, rather than to convert circuit implementation into a fully-automated process.  To this end, the research has produced a public, open-source toolbox available that brings together all analalysis and design techniques developed in the course of the project:

https://potenntial.eecs.utk.edu/toolbox

The toolbox has been deployed in multiple designs across a wide range of applications, showing substantial improvement in the speed and breadth of design optimization.  Because the underlying analytical framework is agnostic to the topology, components, and modulation of the converter, the framework allows unbiased comparison between vastly different approaches to advance power conversion.  

Multiple graduate and undergraduate students were involved in developing and deploying the framework.  All of these students have graduated and accepted full-time positions in US-based technology companies.  Developments from this research have beein integrated into graduate and undergraduate courses at UTK; the content of these courses is detailed in the previously-linked website.  

The research program established the tools and analysis necessary for the PI's long-term career goal: to push forward the boundaries of advanced, high-performance power conversion and to train the future generation of power engineers with skills above and beyond those currently in practice.  The theoretical and software developments in this proposal are broadly applicable to many different designs and applications of power conversion.  Further, by developing capabilities for more intelligent design processes, the research enables new design and analysis techniques far beyond the conclusion of this project.
